comments.commentBody:
No. We were not greater then.
Being drafted wasn't the only way we learned to work together. The Vietnam generation was learning how to work together back home, too. To stop the war. Against dress codes that forced you girls and women to wear dresses or skirts at school and work. For equality. For the environment. Even Woodstock was part of the greatness.

And we are still a great nation.

The difference is that the people aren't in charge any more. The number of millionaires and billionaires has reached critical mass and corporations decide what our choices are. And no, corporations are not people. Then there's the military industrial complex. Back then Eisenhower warned us and we failed to listen.

I've got a 16 year old. There's no way he's going to be conscripted to increase profits for the war machine or to build a wall of separation.

If the people that make this country great were allowed a voice the consensus would be that we've all come to look for America.

Let us be lovers, we'll marry our fortunes together. I've got some real estate here in my bag.....
Disagree. We are not a great nation. We are evil, divided , dysfunctional and destined for destruction. It's happening now.

Yes, Woodstock was wonderful!  They hired me to be a ticket taker and then decided they weren't going to have any tickets so I had to walk home.  But what was wonderful about it all was that it was like one of those wonderful marches against the war only more positive, for music and free minds and spirits and all those good things as my step-grandfather used to say.  Then it just went away like a mirage, and never came back.  We need it now.
That's the point.  If your 16 year old were at risk of being drafted, you'd be a lot more active in resisting the war cry.

Does police brutality exist? Absolutely! However, let us not forget that each officer has their own previous experiences, fears, and personalities (good, bad and ugly) and bring their "baggage" to the job.
Ex: The officer that meekly spoke to the white boy may naturally be a passive person and react to all citizens in that manner. A volital officer may have also been impulsive and angry during his youth-with people of all races.
At what point do we become more selective of the officers we hire and train? Perhaps we pay officers a competitive salary and attract more qualified, stable and college educated officers. I believe we would see a significant decline in police brutality.
Great article!  Hats off to M. Schwartz and the brave Mexican journalists. The article is very pertinent to our times.

The question about the ex-wife and the new girlfriend raises an interesting and I think ongoing problem, not yet addressed, but one which ought to figure into the first wife's decision.

If the ex-wife is correct, we already know that the ex-husband has acquired two beards.

Sure, she can warn number two, but what about the inevitable numbers three, four, five and so on?

It looks like she plans to continue to keep him under surveillance. I think she needs to learn that the only person whose actions she can control, is she. It's time for her to stop trying to manage her ex's affairs.

The lack of commentary on here even mentioning animal agriculture concerns me. Yes, transportation emissions are a contributor to climate change, but livestock and its byproducts are responsible for 32 million tons of CO2 each year (51% of all greenhouse gas emissions).

Methane (the greenhouse gas resulting from animal agriculture) is 25-100 times more destructive than CO2, and has a much higher potential for global warming.

Animal agriculture is responsible for 80-90% of water consumption:
2,500 gallons per 1lb of beef
1,000 gallons per 1 gallon of milk
900 gallons per 1 lb of cheese

Internationally, cows drink 45 billion gallons of water and eat 135 billion lbs of grain each day. We currently grow enough food to feed 10 billion people, but at least 50% of that supply is fed to the livestock. About 82% of starving children live in countries where the food is fed to animals and the animals are eaten by western nations. Starving children exactly like Tsapasoa and Fombasoa.

Reducing consumption of animal products will eventually decrease the impact of the animal agriculture industry. This change is urgent as the animal agriculture industry affects everything and everyone on this planet. Instead of lamenting the condition of the environment through social media posts and shares, please consider how you personally can create change through your actions. Perhaps along the way, compassion for animals will also find a place.

http://www.cowspiracy.com/facts/

The numbers in your first paragraph are completely wrong. World CO2 emissions are about 40 Billion tons per year. Emissions from livestock are under 20% of the total, not 51% as you claimed. The link you provided says 18%. DOT https://climate.dot.gov/about/transportations-role/overview.html says that transportation is responsible for 28% of emissions, electrical generation 33%, industry 20%, agriculture 8%, commercial 6% and residential 5%.
I would much rather drive my gas guzzling pickup to the steakhouse.

You're right. Some of these numbers are a bit off because, in reality, they're much worse. If you look carefully at the provided link, it explains at first that animal agriculture is responsible of 18% of greenhouse gases, more than all of transportation combined, which is only responsible for only for 13%.

But within the link, there are even more sources cited, one of which is a report by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (look in the WorldWatch link) which states in more recent analysis that 32.6 billion tons, not 32 million tons, of CO2 are released each year, which does equal 51%.

We could argue about numbers all day, but the effects of animal agriculture are undeniable. Some sources have been a bit slow to realize its impact, or perhaps don't want to because of what that could mean for the meat and dairy industries, which control a lot more than you would think.

Other sources, like this UN report,

(http://www.unep.org/resourcepanel/Portals/24102/PDFs/PriorityProductsAnd...,

have made it clear that a global shift to a vegan or vegetarian diet is crucial in preserving the planet and diminishing world hunger. In places like Denmark, they are already considering a tax on red meat because of its clear impact on climate change.

Vietnam was a tragedy and profound political and military miscalculation at every step, starting with JFK.

Over 2.7 million US served, 304,000 were injured, 58,154 died and 500,000 still suffer from PTSD today, according to the VA.

The deaths of the Vietnamese include 1.3 million military and up to 2 million civilians. This was followed by another war between Vietnam and the Khmer Rouge.

The lessons of Vietnam were totally lost on Bush-Cheney, who unleashed similar chaos in the Middle East.

But those lessons were clear to President Obama. While the US did the fighting, the Iraqis were fracturing along sectarian lines, Shiite, Sunni and Kurd. Shiite President al Maliki subsequently tried to squeeze as much power and wealth for his cronies, while the half starved Sunni troops ran away at the first ISIS assault, abandoning US weapons and vehicles.

Now Iraqis of all sects are fighting and dying together for their country and slowly defeating ISIS. Right up to the election of Trump, it looked like we avoided another Vietnam.

Now with Fake News Flynn as NSA, almost anything can happen. Its a very troubling time for the men and women who serve in our military.

The most important result of the Vietnam War is the damage done to the people of Southeast Asia, true, but the most important question for us is how these experiences have changed and informed our own country.

Our history can be a great help to us, but only if we approach it as Mr. Marlantes has here, not as a partisan weapon, not as myth and God help us, not as an intellectual fashion statement.

Mr. Marlantes, you have my complete attention.
Actually it started with Truman but Dweight D Eisenhower made the big mistake.

If you are going to lay blame for political and military miscalculation it should be factual.  The French government approached Roosevelt for assistance in Vietnam and he refused.  President Truman eventually sent military advisors and equipment in support of the French in 1950. In 1955 President Eisenhower sent American military to train the Army of the Republic of North Vietnam. 1955 is used as the date that the Vietnam Memorial Committee cites as the beginning of the war in Vietnam. Kennedy wasn't inaugurated until 1961.  And according to sources in Kennedy's cabinet he was considering removing troops and was killed before he could do so.

This article fails to mention a major factor, the export of profits.

Say a company sells something here for a lot of money, a big profit. But it imports one part of that from its own overseas subsidiary, and "pays" a very high price for that part. Now there is no profit in the US. The profit is in the subsidiary, which just happens to be in a place that does not tax that. Magic. No taxes.

Of course that is supposed to be illegal. That is what accountants and lawyers are paid to take care of. It can be handled. It is. Often. For a LOT of money. Trillions.

That money then remains offshore, waiting for a tax amnesty to come home. There have been two recently, and talk of a third.

This system would defeat that. If the cash is spent here, it is taxed here, no matter where they "move" their internal allocation of profit.

Now again, this is supposed to be illegal. There are dodges. It happens in vast amounts. That is why there are trillions waiting for the next tax amnesty. Those who deny it are only saying in public what they say to the IRS -- they have to say it, but we don't have to be so stupid as to believe it.

That distorts the economy too. And collecting tax on all that "distorts" too by making them pay their tax.

Yes, it has its problems and its down sides. Odd that this article makes no slightest mention of this huge upside. Trillions.

He can spend it abroad with gay abandon.  That money could be used to buy expensive objects or more profit making businesses.  Buy a yacht in Cannes and register it wherever it is cheapest.  Rich people don't accept borders or boundaries.  Corporations will do the same.

Most big U.S. headquartered companies are world companies and most of their profits are from foreign sales.  For example, Apple products are designed by foreigners, manufactured by foreigners in foreign factories and then mostly (2/3s) sold to other foreigners in foreign stores.  Why would Apple transfer the profits from those sales to the U.S and pay the full 35% US corporate tax rate on those foreign profits?

"Why would Apple transfer the profits from those sales to the U.S"

Because its owners are here and they want their money. Because its lenders are here and want to be paid. Because the point of a big corporation is that the parts support the whole, and the whole is here in its HQ to deploy money in other ventures.

Of course foreigners in foreign corporations doing business in foreign countries have no reason to pay US tax, but that is not Apple.

The issue is how access the $2.5 trillion that the Fortune 500 has in offshore tax havens, and how to prevent it from happening again. So far the proposal is a 20% tax on imported items; cars, car parts, clothes, gasoline, and for those who care to look pretty much most goods in stores these days. Such a tax will add a dose of reality to the economists who claim that manufacturing employment is down because of automation and not imports, when we see the volume and variety of goods that are taxed because they are imports. If automation were the primary reason for the loss of manufacturing most goods would still state 'Made in the USA', and not be subject to the additional tax for imports.

The concern is how the WTO will view the system, and eventually if other countries would adapt a similar tax policy.

Of course a key selling point of any tax overhaul sponsored by Republicans will be that it's "revenue neutral."  What that means is the share of government taxes paid by corporations won't go up -- they will likely go down as lobbying proceeds.  So while it might address one part of the mess, this overhaul doesn't address the inherent unfairness in the tax system.  But that's not a Republican concern.

The economy is not in a normal state. Polling and interviews show that people voted for Trump because of the abnormality, and a recent paper by Jaimovich and Siu () shows that recent recessions are accompanied by jobless recoveries insofar as routine work is concerned. Automation is here.
Eliminating mind-numbing routine work is not a bad thing--work should not be oppressive--but job displacement is. The economy is in transition: white collar workers have adapted as their jobs became knowledge work, but routine jobs are not a transition to knowledge work. Can the displaced be helped by GOP deficit spending? I very much doubt it, but ignoring the issue does the public a disservice.

I'm sure I'm not the first to point this out, but an aardvark is not the same thing as an anteater, and so an anteater is also not the same thing as an antbear. Not to be too snide, but I would think that someone who loves anteaters would be able to distinguish them from aardvarks.

Aardvarks eat ants. Not surprisingly, one name for them in Africa is "anteater."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aardvark

I think Deb deserves a hug.

From M-W:

Definition of antbear
: aardvark

Deb deserves much more than a hug.

I find the anti-Russia hysteria being whipped up quite remarkable. People's critical faculties are paralyzed with disorientation and fear. Like after 9/11, when trumped up WMD tall tales set the world on a path towards ISIS and God-knows what next. Have no Americans heard of the NED --- the National Endowment for Democracy? Ask the Venezuelans, for example, about U.S. meddling in elections. Espionage and counter-espionage go on all, the time. It is an endless game. Like you and your personal data, which everyone and their uncle helps themselves to every minute of every day. What is never at issue in these stories about Russia! are the nasty little tricks the DNC did to keep Bernie out of the White House and the Clinton campaign's lousy strategy, especially in the closing days of the election. What you have are the neoliberals/necons/cold warrior establishment types trying to keep their hand son the wheel and lunatic Republicans poised to drive the USA -- is not the entire world -- off a cliff. I just happened to be reading chapter one of Robert O. Paxton's definitive work. "The Anatomy of Fascism," where he describes the confused despondency that followed WWI, an atmosphere for which left and right were inadequate and that occurred because liberal and conservative had failed. Like now. Uncertainly, jockeying for power. It is truly remarkable how shameless propaganda actually can be. All those governments toppled by the CIA denied with a straight face.

Shoddy attempt at deflection Bill. You reveal yourself with the false claim the CIA lied about WMD in Iraq. False, it is well documented that Cheney made up the WMD story and tired to pin it on the CIA which they vehemently denied at the time. The other points about US meddling, some of which are true are irrelevant to the discussion at hand, Russian interference in the 2016 election. I was appalled as you but not surprised at the DNC's orchestrating the coronation of Hillary, it was obvious in 2014.

If you are as concerned about fascism as you indicate how can you not see the inherent fascism of Donald Trump? Parroting debunked stories does not enhance your credibility Bill. US meddling in other countries affairs has been going on for decades, Iran, Chile, Iraq are but a few examples but have nothing do with the discussion at hand, flat out deflection.
Patricians - Speaking of high horses, I'm sure you "know for a fact" that Trump will fail to enforce a NATO defense against Putin's aggression, right?
Keith: I am having difficulty finding words i have written to the effect that I am not concerned about Trump's authoritarian inclination and expansive sense of entitlement.

There is a direct correlation between the decline in the quality and content of our education and the rise of alternate news realities that growing segments of our population accept. We've come to the point where depending on where one stands in this polarized society, they will only accept the news that are meted out by like-minded outlets. It used to be that "crazy" was relegated to the Inquirer and most people accepted what they read in Time, Newsweek, Washington Post, and the New York Times.

The way to undo the damage done by the Foxification of our news, ultimately, is to make foundational correction in the single biggest inequity in our society. What is the one thing all members of the elite get? An excellent education, founded on the best, broadest font of knowledge in the humanities.

How did Trump, a man whose expressive language is of a very young 8 year old make such an impact on so many millions of voters and to on to get elected? Ronald Dworkin was right, our declining system of education has put democracy at-risk: http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-1pI Where did Steve Bannon go to school after a stint in the Navy? Georgetown University. He got an elite education. Where did Ted Cruz get his education? He went to Harvard.

Give every citizen in every state the same high-quality public education, from pre-K to 12th grade. http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-1qI Make college, whether technical or academic, free. That is how Breitbart and Fox News will be made irrelevant.

Knowledge is broad, G.H. and the kind of education I am talking about focuses on the acquisition of language and critical thinking as a building block of learning. The humanities are neither progressive nor conservative. Your belief that it is is indoctrination that is deep-seated in American society to curtail interest in education.
nytimes was very partisan this election cycle.
Thank you! Couldn't have said it better!
Sorry, but the clue should be FBI'S DEPT, not FBI'S DIV.

Martin,
I would love to see your response to Steve L's question.

All kinds of rules can be broken for a theme.  "Courtney" is not part of the entry.  "CLOVE" is.  The constructor and editor agreed that using "Courtney" as part of the clue was fair, as more oblique references to the person would make the concept too difficult.  It's a conscious decision to break a rule to make a theme.

I assumed that would be your response to Steve L, Martin (and no, this is not SNL).  My only surprise was that you did not make it at the same time that you responded to Rock.  I understand that "rules" can get broken for a theme; I don't agree that the rule needed to be broken in the example you cite.   Clued as it is, it gives away the first letter of the entry, but I suspect as many people would know "Kurt's widow" as "Singer Courtney."  I preferred the theme clues that did not include the first name.

"Vietnam changed us as a country. In many ways, for the worse: It made us cynical and distrustful of our institutions, especially of government."

Those were not the first times our government lied to us. It was not even in the first century of lies. Read Abraham Lincoln about the Mexican War, about which he said the same things while running for Congress.

We are not changed for the worse, if we catch on, finally.

We'd be for the worse if the lies were new, if this had not been happening.

It is all for the best if we finally figure it out, catch on, hold our government to a higher standard, finally.

For awhile after Vietnam, we harbored a distrust was called the Vietnam Syndrome, and it limited government wars and inhibited government lies (didn't end them).

Then the Persian Gulf War victory euphoria "cured" us of the Vietnam Syndrome.

Then we trusted again, for a short while, even through Bill Clinton's shenanigans. Until finally W and Cheney got hold of power and showed us some of the mothers of all lies.

Are we worse for knowing? Or were we worse for trusting W and Cheney?

I'd say it is not worse, not even cynical, to distrust what ought to be distrusted.
Our own government is a greater threat to our welfare than any foreign entity today.

My present attitude is one of open-minded skepticism. I get my news from a variety of newspapers including this one and Haaretz, the BBC World Service and Radio 4, Kol Israel, and as many other sources as I can. I am 70 years old and retired, so I have plenty of time to do this. I don't have access to as many books as I used to which I regret.

You don't have to rely on social media and cable television to keep up with what is going on in the world. I'm sorry that it isn't easier and cheaper to keep up, but it is a lot easier than it used to be when people in the US used to have to wait for Walter Cronkite to tell you what was going on if they couldn't or wouldn't listen to the Voice of Vietnam, and they lied too.

My god, DL, that sounds awful, and I remember from Psych 1 that each repetition only increases one's aversion to a painful or unpleasant experience. I wonder if maybe that amnesiac kind of agent could at least make it seem like the experience never happened, but I guess you and your docs have considered that to no avail. Here's to next Wednesday.
Oh, but so many of us have the ability--the ability to become parents.  That's the rub.

Anything that eliminates corporations leaving the United States, because of high corporate tax rates, and becoming domiciled in foreign nations, such as Ireland, where the effective tax, as is the case with Apple, is 2%, is a very good thing, and long overdue.

It seems the United States of America has been relegated to be the insatiable maw, for products made anywhere but in the United States, specifically designed for the enrichment of the global elite.
With the new rules Apple will sell at 2% taxes abroad and at say 20% in USA. That means that no money will enter from Apple Irland to USA.
I am appalled at the percentages quoted here--40-50% of babies are insecure?  That's horrid!
That's an utterly meaningless statistic.  What does "insecure" mean, and how do you measure it numerically?

There is a reason this piece is in the opinion section. The study the author cites  is 30 years old, a whole other universe ago in terms of parenting, and is not intended to develop general percentages of unattached children. It's a poorly chosen and outdated piece of evidence. Murphy also ignores the current interest in the fact that babies, too, have personalities, which impact how parents respond to them. Murphy has a personal Mommy-War agenda (which is why this is in the opinion section). That said, all the research agrees that if your infant (under 6 months) is crying, absolutely pick her up promptly.

None of the attachment theorists account for the most important variable: what if the failure to attach is due to a problem inherent in the baby's brain? Some babies don't produce sufficient oxytocin. That, and not bad parenting, is a better explanation for the failure to attach. The idea that up to 50% of parents are so deficient as to cause attachment problems is absurd

Your statement that the new tax arrangement eliminates "the incentive to play games with overseas companies" seems to miss a key point.  If overseas affiliate companies continue to own the valuable intellectual property (e.g. Apple's iPhone technology) then the domestic company must pay the foreign company to use the technology -- the cash leaves the US and goes to an affiliated company overseas in a low tax jurisdiction. That reduces domestic cash flow and accordingly reduces the tax under the new structure.  I don't see that the new arrangement addresses offshoring of intellectual property for tax avoidance.   The effect would be similar to the existing situation: cash piles up overseas in low tax jurisdictions.

Kieth -- as I understand it from "A company that imported goods worth $80 from abroad and them sold them domestically for $100 would pay tax on the full $100" the "intellectual property" is an imported good and so there's no tax shifting from it.

I'm trying to understand this tax, and I may not have it right, but this tax appears to amount to a sort-of VAT in disguise with the additional wrinkle that imports are treated as zero-value of cost-of-goods; all taxes due on import.

There's a big problem i can see with this tax -- hobby corporations and self-dealing.

This tax rate will be a LOT lower than most people's personal tax rates. Let's say I run the "Harrison Consulting Company" (I did in the past) and I pay myself a dollar per year, on which I pay income tax. This company owns my house, owns my car the rest of my toys, pays my living expenses as i define them -- these are all deductions to the company -- as this article explains it every purchase is an immediate deduction! Wow!

If the company is making money its held capital increases and I can eventually get that out as capital gains. The cumulative taxation on that is the product of this pseudo-VAT times the capital gains rate ... and that's a lot cheaper than most not-poor-people's personal tax rate.

This sure looks like a sweet, sweet deal for everybody who wants to play the game: it makes "personal income taxes are for suckers" ... as sadly they always have been. But this gives it steroids.
Refering the coment of CGS: the distinction between tangible and ideal goods nowerdays has no sense. The licence will be paid as a part of the price of the product or the data flow.

Incidentally -- just to clarify -- everything I am suggesting in this "example" violates the precepts of IRS publication 15 about non-cash compensation.

But the sad fact of the matter is that these issues are among the most flagrantly-violated ones of the tax code, and almost nobody gets caught for any of it.

Remember Mrs. Romney's "hobby business" of owning a very expensive dressage horse named Rafalca? That business generated tax losses for the Romneys ... and is the poster-child of an abusive hobby-business run to scam the tax system.

Did anybody really complain about the direct abuse, when Romney ran? No. There was a little tut-tutting, but abusive hobby companies are the free-play zone of America.

And quite beyond that, NOBODY had the temerity to suggest that Mrs. Romney was subject to the pub 15 regulations on non-wage compensation ... that she needed to pay income tax on the lease-rate for Rafalca, that would instantly quash the whole thing.
DL—When the waiting room TV is on Fox "News," either they agree to change the channel or turn it off, or they have seen the last of me at that office.

Aardvarks eat ants. Not surprisingly, one name for them in Africa is "anteater."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aardvark

I think Deb deserves a hug.
Seeing as the "D" in DOJ is "department," the clue had to avoid that word.

A 500% improvement in shootings is so dramatic that I distrust the report.

Instead, I fear apples to oranges in the comparison.

I'd want someone who really understands the numbers to consider and explain that, before I would trust it.

Too good to be true is generally not true. See Bernie Madoff.
Richard: I live in the worst crime precinct in the history of New York, the 75!  Believe me, the numbers are real.  Compared to 1990, our quality of life is much, much better.  No ifs ands or buts.
The 500% improvement is not in the report. That comes from a comment by the Mayor citing the change over 25 years.

Lawrence -- I wrote distrust, not reject, a word choice with a reason.

Given our current politics of the lie, I think we need an Editorial to address the underlying numbers rather than just accept a government claim of something so dramatic.

It need not be itself devoted to a re-exam of the numbers, but it at least should cite someone credible doing a review of them, and perhaps a few of the relevant considerations considered important by that review.

I have in mind an editor giving the writer a skeptical eye, and demanding more to back up the story.

Crime reduction hits directly at deprivations of civil rights. It is also about justifying policing tactics at the expense of certain communities. It is extremely political, rather like credulous acceptance of claims of WMD, which the NYT also indulged without proper exam.

I'm saying we need more from the best paper we've got, because our political culture has slid too far.

As for these particular numbers, I have not examined the report myself. It is a generic distrust of dramatic government claims of facts convenient to government.

What defines what we all know or should know? I was surprised to find that there is no single definition for "common font or fount of knowledge." See http://www.rimaregas.com/2015/06/common-font-of-knowledge-defining-what-...
